{{Infobox musical artist |image= | name = DJ Kay Slay | birth_name = Keith Grayson | alias = The Drama King, Dezzy Dez | background = non_performing_personnel | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1966|08|14|mf=yes}} | death_date = | origin = [[New York City]], [[New York]], U.S. | genre = [[East Coast hip hop]] | occupation = [[disc jockey|DJ]] | years_active = 1983âpresent | label = [[Streetsweepers Entertainment|Streetsweepers]]
[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]/[[Sony Music Entertainment|SME Records]] | associated_acts = [[Ray J]], [[Busta Rhymes]], [[Fat Joe]], [[50 Cent]], [[Lloyd Banks]], [[Tony Yayo]], }} '''DJ Kay Slay''' (akas: The Drama King, Dezzy Dez, Slap Your Favorite DJ) is an [[United States|American]] hip hop [[deejay]]. He was referred to by the ''[[New York Times]]'' as "Hip Hop's One-Man Ministry of Insults". He has sold 350,000 copies of his two official albums.[http://www.nobodysmiling.com/hiphop/news/86337.php DJ Kay Slay and Shaq Seek to Bridge the Gap] ==Early life== '''Keith Grayson''' was originally a prominent [[graffiti]] artist. He was featured in the 1983 hip hop documentary [[Style Wars]]. With decline of the graffiti movement in the late 1980s, Dez began dealing with narcotics and consequently ended up in jail by the early 1990s. ==''Streetsweeper'' albums== Kayslay released his first album, ''Streetsweeper Vol. 1'' on 20 May 2003. In the summer of 2003, Kayslay released a single and [[music video]] of his own for a track called "Too Much For Me". It featured rapping from [[Baby (rapper)|Baby]], [[Nas (rapper)|Nas]], and [[Foxy Brown (rapper)|Foxy Brown]], and a chorus sung by then relative newcomer, [[Amerie]]. There were cameo appearances by [[Swizz Beatz]], [[N.O.R.E.]], [[Raekwon]], [[WC (rapper)|WC]] and [[Lloyd Banks]]. {{citation needed|date=December 2009}} Although the song was not a success, its music video was aired on [[MTV Jams]] and [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]]. The Too Much For Me Music Video did not feature [[Nas (rapper)|Nas]] (because of Nas' solo projects) or [[Baby (rapper)|Baby]]; so [[Loon (rapper)|Loon]] was featured instead. This replacement started a feud between [[Nas (rapper)|Nas]] and Kayslay. On March 30, 2004, Kayslay's second album ''Streetsweeper Vol. 2'' was released. Another single and video were released for "Who Gives A...Where You From" with [[Three 6 Mafia]]. Kayslay and the song were featured on the 2004 [[NFL Street]] [[video game]]. {{citation needed|date=December 2009}} ==Discography== ===Solo albums=== {|class="wikitable" !rowspan="2"|Year
